byline.contributor: James C. McKinley Jr. and Mireya Navarro contributed reporting from New York.

abstract: Juvenile justice reform advocates praise New York Gov Andrew Cuomo's plan to offer pardons to thousands of people convicted of nonviolent felonies or misdemeanors at age 16 or 17 who have gone at least 10 years since without any additional convictions; supporters say pardons will ease stigma of criminal convictions and help those pardoned to seek productive lives; some critics express concern at state's ability to vet records of 10,000 people who may qualify.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is seeking to pardon people convicted of nonviolent crimes when they were 16 or 17, but proponents say more is needed to address the collateral effects of the juvenile records.

headline.main: Cuomo’s Pardon Plan for Youthful Offenders Draws Praise, Questions and Concerns
